John Andrew Leavell, 2, of Bagley, MN, died on Friday, July 19, 2024, at the Sanford Fargo Medical Center.

Funeral services will be held on Friday, July 26, 2024, at 2 p.m. at Country Faith Church in Clearbrook, MN, with a visitation one hour prior. The Cease Family Funeral Home of Bagley assisted the family with arrangements.

John was born on June 17, 2022, in Bemidji, MN, to Matthew and Heather (Pixler) Leavell.

Johnny loved his family. He loved snuggling with Dad in the evening. His favorite toys were whatever his brother and sisters had, especially cars, school buses and tractors. He loved his chickens and gardening with Mommy. He had a special bond with, and loved his daycare family. John attended and was loved by Thriving Life Church.

His light shone bright in his life and he will be tremendously missed.

John is survived by his parents, Matt and Heather Leavell; his siblings, Elizabeth, David, and Emelia; his grandparents, Suzen Pixler, and Randy and Diane Leavell; his adoptive grandparents, Terry and Loralee Nennich; his great grandpa, Carl Leavell; and many aunts uncles, cousins, and other loved family members.

He is preceded in death by his grandfather, David Pixler.

Messages of condolence may be sent to ceasefuneralhome.com

Erick (“Doc”) Reeber, who lived his childhood dream of being a small-town country doctor, passed away peacefully in his sleep at age 93 surrounded by family.

Erick was born in Brooklyn, NY, the child of immigrants Paul (Pinchas) and Ray (Rivka) (nee Schacter) Reeber. Erick grew up in a tiny one room studio apartment behind the corner drugstore his father ran. He graduated from Stuyvesant High School at age 16, then won a New York Regents Scholarship, attending the University of Buffalo with a major in mathematics. In his junior year of college, he was awarded a Regents Scholarship covering the cost of medical school and received his Doctor of Medicine from the University of Buffalo in 1956.

While an undergraduate, he met and fell in love with Jane Mitchell Larke. They soon married and remained married until her death in 2012. Together, they had four children.

After medical residency in Elmira, NY, Erick joined the Navy Medical Corps where he was stationed in San Francisco and sailed the Pacific Ocean. When his active duty ended, he continued in the Navy Reserves achieving the rank of Commander before retiring from service after 34 years. While serving his country, he earned the Armed Forces Service Medal for his years of service.

He joined a medical practice in Thief River Falls, MN in 1959, followed by a solo practice in Frazee, MN.

In 1964, he joined the Clearwater Clinic in Bagley, MN where he built up his practice, eventually leaving to again have a solo practice in Bagley. He kept the clinic open until 1995 when he “retired”.

Erick loved all aspects of medicine, whether delivering babies, figuring out a subtle medical issue that other doctors missed, serving on the local hospital board, or working with other doctors to address issues in health care.

And, yes, he made house calls, sometimes via snowmobile.

He took great pride in having some of the lowest fees of any family doctor in Minnesota and was happy to take a jar of honey or a side of beef as payment. For financially struggling patients, as long as they had always made monthly payments (even just a dollar a month), he sometimes provided a small low interest loan to cover an emergency expense.

He was considered an excellent doctor, not only by his patients, but by other doctors as well for his ability to diagnose difficult cases. Specialists to whom he had referred patients sometimes wrote to tell him, “If you had not told me where to look, I would not have found the problem.” Yet, when the University of Minnesota’s Medical School asked him to join their faculty, he said he preferred to remain a small-town country doctor. After closing his practice, he continued to fill in at the VA hospital until he had a small stroke at age 69. He remained active on many medical and cultural boards well into his eighties.

In 2014, he moved to Grand Forks to Valley Senior Living on 42nd street, where he was known for his stories, jokes, and poetry recitations.

Erick was also an avid stamp collector, bird watcher, and supporter of local cultural, scientific, educational, and art organizations. The Royal Philatelic Society of London made him a Fellow for his contributions to the understanding of Madagascar British Consular Mail. He and Jane traveled the world to bird watch. He served for many years on the board of “Farm by the Lake” in Bagley and contributed to many other local organizations.

Surviving him is his brother Morton (Zelda) Reeber, his sister-in-law Anne Schneider, four children–Larke (Jack Fendell) Reeber, Katherine (Leo) Arnold, Andrew (Debbie) Reeber, Martha (Van) Janway, eight grandchildren–Crystal (Ron) Blue, Erick (Emily) Arnold, May Fendell, Caitlin (Jason) Buschmann, Samuel (Soumya Suresh) Fendell, Rae Vander Werf, Corianne (Josh) Petersen, Benjamin Reeber, eight great-grandchildren, one foster great-grandchild, four nieces and nephews, and five great-nieces and nephews. He was preceded in death by his wife, his parents, and an infant granddaughter.

Burial was at Fort Snelling on July 15 with full military honors. His wife Jane’s ashes were interred with him. There will be a memorial event for both of them in Bagley on September 14. For details, email reebermem@yahoo.com or call 218-308-6361. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made to the “Farm by the Lake” in Bagley or another cultural, educational, scientific, or art organization.

Justin Aaron Lindgren, 43, son of Doug & Colleen Lindgren of Bagley, passed away in Tempe, AZ on June 21, 2024.

Funeral services will be held on Friday, July 12th, 3 p.m. at the Cease Family Funeral Home in Bagley. Visitation will be held one hour before the service. Lunch will be served immediately following the service in the Bagley American Legion Auditorium. Burial will be in the Bagley City Cemetery at a later time.

Justin was born June 23, 1980, at the Clearwater County Memorial Hospital in Bagley. He graduated from Bagley High School in 1998, Bemidji Vo-Tec, and attended Bemidji State University for several years. He worked in the food and beverage industry for many years in the Bemidji/Duluth area where he made some amazing friends, and many became like family to him. He also was a Service Writer for Firestone Tires in Duluth before he moved to Phoenix, AZ, in January of 2015 where he worked for several different restaurants and finally for the last 4.5 years at Dick’s Sporting Goods as an Order Fulfillment Manager.

He is survived by his parents; Doug & Colleen (Smith) Lindgren of Bagley; brother Jeremiah Lindgren of Fargo, ND; sister Rebekah (Jhonny) Jimenez of Clearbrook; niece Payton Jimenez; nephew Johnny Jimenez; special “adopted” niece Sadie of Phoenix; God Father Lyle Smith and God Mother Marie Boon; many special aunts, uncles, cousins, too many friends to list and his beloved fur baby Lunna who saw him through all the highs and lows after his precious dog Tessa passed.

Justin loved hugs and gave them to everyone. Whether you wanted one or not he just knew you needed or wanted one and you got it. He loved spending time with his friends in Phoenix no matter what they were doing (especially if it involved sports such as watching the Twins, Dodgers or the Cleveland Browns, for some reason), off-road jeeping with Cole Christensen, watching TV/hanging out or spending time with Marlon Chee on the Shooting range, telling bad jokes or going out to eat as both guys were so very special to him. He loved phone calls and just talking whether to family or friends. One other pass time was calling his siblings with jokes, starting to laugh and simply hanging up just to call back a bit later with another. The sad part of all this is that Justin was moving home the middle of July to begin a new job in Fargo after being away for 9 years.

Justin will be missed by so many people he touched in one way or another. “Remember all the good times.” he would say and he always knew if you needed a hug. So, just ask and he will send one down to you from the Heavens.

He is joining his Grandparents, Cousins, Tessa and other family and friends in Heaven.

Marilyn Jean Lewis was born on April 18, 1932 in Bagley, MN. Her parents were Oscar Edward Lewis, an attorney, and Laura Margaret (Jensen) Lewis, a teacher.

Marilyn was also known as Jeanie when she was growing up. One of the memories she loved to share was about the time she and two friends went sliding down “hospital hill” in Bagley and ended up sliding right under a cow! Marilyn attended Bagley High School, graduating in 1950 as the valedictorian in her class. In high school she received awards for Instrumental Music, Band, Speech, Vocal Music, and Hi-Life.

After high school Marilyn attended Macalester College, where she met Edward Rasmussen. In 1952 they married and started a family in St. Paul. In 1953 Marilyn graduated from Macalester with a BA in Spanish. In 1964 they moved to Bagley with their four young children. Marilyn lived in Bemidji for several years before moving to Edina in 1989. Since 2021 she has lived at The Waters of Eden Prairie. Marilyn died on June 28, 2024, with her children and their families by her side.

Marilyn worked in real estate sales after receiving her Real Estate License in 1977. In 1983 Marilyn earned an MS degree in Education, with a Major in Counseling, from Bemidji State University. In 1986 Marilyn received a Paralegal Certificate from the MN Association of Legal Assistants. She also held several jobs in sales and worked in

modeling (with the most beautiful smile you have ever seen). For many years she worked at an accounting firm, where she had some very dear friends.

Marilyn loved music. She played clarinet in Band & Orchestra in high school and college. Her solo clarinet music and solo piano music was very difficult. She sang in choirs everywhere, including church choirs wherever she lived. Marilyn was a member of Sweet Adelines in Bemidji and a member of the Colonial Chorale of Edina for many years. She traveled with the Chorale, to Great Britain in 1987, and, to Europe in 1990, to tour and perform concerts. She later joined the Edina Singing Seniors and loved performing with them, and their outstanding pianist.

Marilyn was a voracious reader and loved reading nonfiction. She also loved to drink coffee and dark beer, eat caramel rolls, golf, bike, ski, skate, work out at a health club, attend chamber orchestra, opera, jazz, comedy, theater, and the US Marine band. She enjoyed the Minnesota Twins, art, architecture, history, travel, movies, and animals. Marilyn loved talking to anyone she met, and the funnier and cleverer the conversation could get, the better.

She was an avid water skier and snowmobiler while she lived in Bagley, raising her family. After moving to the Twin Cities, she became an avid cross-country skier, skiing on many beautiful trails around Minnesota. She loved any time with her kids, grandkids and great grandkids. She had many fall “leafing” trips around Lake Itasca and the North Shore, as well as many fishing trips to Upper Red Lake with her kids. Marilyn enjoyed traveling with friends and daughters to other fun and beautiful places.

Marilyn is survived by her four children: Jon Rasmussen (Deborah Capouch) of Bloomington; Pamela Rasmussen (James Johnson) of Minnetonka; Paul Rasmussen (Cynthia Mireault) of Bagley; and Susan Rasmussen (Karl Erickson), of Blackduck; six grandchildren: Harmony Kane (Stephen); Amanda Phakonkham (Says); Derek Rasmussen; Katrina Rasmussen; Justen Rasmussen (Michelle); and Laura Hawk (Jared); and five great-grandchildren: Ava, Ian, and Eli Phakonkham, Saoirse Kane, and Harper Hawk. She is also survived by her brother, James Lewis of Pinewood, and several nieces and nephews.

A Celebration of Life will be held on Saturday, July 13, from 2:00 p.m. to 7:00 p.m. for family and friends at the Hughes Pavilion, at Centennial Lakes Park, 7499 France Ave., S., Edina, MN 55435.

In lieu of flowers, please consider giving a memorial donation to a charity that is important to you.

Keith Dee Barcus, 76, of Bemidji, Minnesota passed away on June 29, 2024, doing what he loved in the great outdoors – trapping his gophers.

Funeral services will be held at 11:00 am, Friday, July 5, 2024, at Evangelical Covenant Church in Bemidji, MN. Visitation will be two hours prior to the service. Interment will be at the Shevlin City Cemetery in Shevlin, MN under the direction of the Cease Family Funeral Home in Bemidji.

Keith was born on September 6, 1947, to Douglas and Jennie (Wobbema) Barcus in Grand Rapids, Minnesota. In 1956, they moved the family to Shevlin, Minnesota. Keith was baptized and confirmed at the Clearwater Lutheran Church in Shevlin. Keith attended Shevlin Elementary School and Bagley High School, graduating in 1965. In 1966, Keith was drafted into the United States Army and served his country with honor during the Vietnam War from 1967 to 1968. After serving his Country, Keith attended the VoTech in Bemidji for carpentry. His first job was with Nu Ply. Keith then worked for Northwestern Bell and retired from Quest Telephone in 2004. Keith married Linda (Clemenson) Barcus on January 21, 1983, in Nashville, Tennessee. Together they joined their loving families. He was a shining example of what it means to be a loving husband, dad, father-in-law and grandpa!

Keith loved the great outdoors! He was known as “Rambo” by all his family and friends. He had the most loving heart and was a friend to everyone he met. In the fall, he would spend time hunting on his family farm in Shevlin with his kids and grandkids. Montana was another favorite spot to hunt with his hunting buddies. After retirement, he spent many years traveling to Colorado, elk guiding for Beaver Creek Outfitters. Most recently, he hunted at his son’s farm in Pinewood from his Taj Mahal deer stand. During the winter months, Keith would be the first one to brave the ice to set up the spear house on Lake Bemidji while the rest of us were bringing in our docks. Besides spearing northern, he was the self-appointed lake road crew making sure all the roads were plowed for everyone to get to their fish houses. In the spring and summer months he spent endless hours at his Family Resort – Wildview Lodge on Little Island Lake in the Bovey area. His kids and grandkids have amazing memories, great life lessons, hunting and fishing, driving the golf cart, gardening, swimming with the cousins, and visiting with all the resort guests. Recently, Keith became known as the “King of Gopher Trapping,” rising at dawn to tirelessly control the critters plaguing local farmers. Known for his incredible luck, Keith seemed to win a gun at every banquet he attended. Keith had simple pleasures too; he found joy in watching Wheel of Fortune and spent his evenings checking his gopher traps.

Keith was truly like no other. His loyalty to his family and friends was unparalleled, a testament to his generous spirit and kind heart. His bond with veterans was deep-rooted and meaningful. Throughout his life, Keith demonstrated immense strength and resilience, particularly in his journey to overcome the scars of war. His active participation in the Vietnam PTSD group not only provided him with a support network, but also played a crucial role in his life. Keith found solace and companionship in his fellow veterans, as they shared their experiences, hardships, and triumphs. Additionally, Keith was an avid member of the In Country Vietnam Motorcycle Club. Keith’s involvement in these groups not only brought him joy and purpose but also served as a testament to his unwavering resilience and determination. Every year, he eagerly participated in the Ride for the Troops, always riding behind the group to assist anyone whose bike encountered engine trouble.

Keith is survived by his beloved wife Linda and leaves behind a cherished legacy in his children and grandchildren: Sheila (John) Eckman and their children Kendra (Cameron) and Caden of Fosston, Minnesota; Mandi Fontaine (Jarrod) and her children Brendyn (Alex) Scouton and Sean (Rylee) Fontaine, great-grandchildren Carter and Luca of Wrenshall, Minnesota; Eric (Jana) Norgaard and their children Matthew and Jack of Bemidji, Minnesota; and Chris (Jenny) Norgaard and their children Addie & Gunnar of Bismark, North Dakota. He is also survived by his siblings Kent (Connie) Barcus and Dee Christopherson and remembered fondly by his brother and sister-in-laws: Dennis (Harriet) Clemenson, Sharon (James) Solien, Cindy (Jerry) Erickson, and Sandy (Ken) Charpentier plus numerous nieces, nephews, and cousins.

Keith has now been reunited with his parents Douglas (Georgine) Barcus, Jennie (Herman) Lepley, his sister Janice Parson, sister-in-law Susan Paulson, brother-in-law Cleo Christopherson, brother-in-law Dick Watne and nephew Chad Westrum. His memory will forever be cherished by his family and friends whose lives he touched deeply with his warmth, generosity, and unwavering love.

Sarah Jean Anderson (née Maruska) passed away at her home in Bagley, MN on June 26, 2024. Sarah was the 3rd daughter born to Bennet and Wendy Maruska (née Huss) on January 23, 1982, in Waconia, MN. She was happily welcomed home by her two older sisters Gale and Denise. Sarah was a happy child who loved to suck her thumb and roll her favorite pillowcase. She loved Carebears and spending time with her sisters and was excited to become a big sister to Trisha and Amber who rounded out the family of 5 girls!

Sarah attended preschool in Delano, MN before finishing the rest of her primary education in Bagley, MN. She graduated from Bagley High School in 2000 and completed her 4-year degree in business management online. School was easy for Sarah, as she excelled in math and enjoyed reading. Sarah had a heart of gold and had several jobs that involved caring for others, such as working at Pine Ridge Residence group home for disabled adults in Bagley.

Shortly after graduating, Sarah moved in with her oldest sister Gale in Sterling, Virgina, where she worked as a Manager at Blockbuster Video and Sharper Image. She made new friends easily and they were an eclectic group, varying from Japanese anime fans to aspiring WWE wrestlers. While working at Blockbuster, she had to learn how to pronounce “bag” in an East Coast accent, as the customers did not understand her when she asked in her MN accent, “do you wanna ‘beg’ for that?” Sarah enjoyed going to movies, hanging out with her friends and touring local historic sites with her big sister, such as the memorials in Washington, D.C. Sarah enjoyed her time on the East Coast, but decided to move back to Bagley, MN to be closer to the rest of her family in 2004.

On September 2, 2006, Sarah married Jerod Anderson at the home of Jill and Jeff Anderson. Five months later on February 19, 2007, they welcomed their first child Haylee Christine Anderson followed by Alexis Lynn Anderson on January 13, 2009, and Jayden Jefferey William Anderson on September 30, 2011. Sarah loved her children and enjoyed spending time with them at the fair, parks, and with family in Louisiana. Sarah and Jerod divorced in 2022.

Sarah is preceded in death by her father and stepmother Bennet Gale and Diana Maruska, maternal grandfather Wendell Huss, paternal grandparents Raymond and Elsie Maruska, stepbrother Kyle Knutson, and several aunts and uncles. She is survived by her children Hailey, Alexis, and Jayden, mother Wendy (Klay) Knutson, maternal grandmother Genevieve Huss, sisters Gale (Andrew) McCandlish, nephews Max and Sam McCandlish, Denise Monson, nephew and nieces Brolin, Diem, and Ashlynn Monson, Trisha (Nick) Martinka, nephews and niece Kameryn, Brendin, and Charly Martinka, and Amber (Josh) Lorenz, nephews Kemper and Sawyer Lorenz, stepbrother Derrick (Brandi) Knutson, niece and nephews Taybryn, Dwayne, and Carter Klayton Knutson, and several aunts, uncles, and cousins.

The family will welcome visitors Tuesday, July 2, 2024, at 1:00 p.m., with a memorial service to follow at 2:00 p.m. at Cease Family Funeral Home, 407 Getchell Avenue NE, Bagley, MN 56621. Reception will follow directly after the memorial service at the Bagley American Legion, 112 Main Ave. N., Bagley, MN 56621. Additional details, including a space to share your memories or leave a condolence message, can be found at ceasefuneralhome.com.

Arthur Douglas Tobkin, age 81, of Bagley, MN, a loving and gentle man of deep faith, peacefully “slipped the surly bonds of Earth” on Wednesday, June 26, 2024, at Sanford Medical Center in Fargo, ND.

Funeral Mass Services will be held at 11:00 AM on Monday, July 8, 2024, at St. Joseph’s Catholic Church in Bagley, Minnesota with Father JohnMelkies Suvakeen and Father Dave Super officiating. Visitation will take place 2 hours prior to the service at the church from 9:00 am – 11:00 am. And also, one hour prior to the services at the church. Interment will be held at the St. Joseph’s Catholic Cemetery in Bagley, Minnesota. Military honors will be accorded by the Irvin Blix American Legion Post #16 of Bagley, MN. The Cease Family Funeral Home of Bagley assisted the family with arrangements.

A longtime resident of Bagley, MN, Art was born to James and Dorothy (Rohr) Tobkin on April 8, 1943. Art grew up on a farm NE of Detroit Lakes, MN. He completed his first six years of school in a one room schoolhouse two miles SE of the family farm. He graduated from Detroit Lakes High School in 1960.

After graduation, Art entered the U.S. Navy with duties in Great Lakes, IL, Naval Air Technical Training Center in Millington, TN and North Island Naval Air Station, near Coronado, CA. Art was assigned to VP-31, the Replacement Air Group Squadron for the Pacific Fleet. He was an Aircrewman, flying as a Radio Operator in Martin Marlin P5M-2 seaplanes. Art completed his active military obligation on March 27, 1964.

After returning to MN, Art was employed by the Minnesota Highway Department in St. Paul; working on highway construction until he began attending University of Minnesota in September 1964. He also joined the Naval Air Reserve at the Twin Cities Naval Air Station, where he continued his duties as an Aircrewman, flying as a Radio Operator in Lockheed Neptune P2V-7 aircraft until the closure of the Naval Station in 1970.

The focus of Art’s life was his family, his church and his fellow veterans. Art’s sister, Jeanette, introduced him to Leona “Lee” Mary Reinert, the love of his life. They were married at St. Mary’s Catholic Church in Bird Island, MN on September 18, 1965. The lived briefly in St. Paul and then bought a home in Maplewood. Art continued working at the Highway Department and attended night school, graduating in 1970 with a BS in Civil Engineering.

In 1976, Art, Lee and five children moved to Bagley when he accepted employment as the Clearwater County Engineer. He left the county in 1987 and began his career as a Sales Engineer for Elk River Concrete Products, a division of Cretex Companies. He retired in 2004.

Art was an active member of St. Joseph’s church where he served as a Lector, Usher, Eucharistic Minister and Ecclesiastical Lay Minister, as well as, a member of the Pastoral, Finance, Liturgical and Cemetery Sexton.

Art was also very active in The American Legion. He was Post Commander and District Commander. He served as Chairman on various committees, including Post Honor Guard, Post Education Committee and the Department of Minnesota Americanism. Art was proud of his service to the country and cared deeply for his fellow veterans.

Art is now reunited with his parents Jim and Dorothy, sisters Jeanette, Donna Jean, infant brother Nicholas and son-law Jack Gerbracht.

Art is survived by his wife of 58 years Lee: five children Denise (Brian) Roy; Sara (Eric) Fitch, Paul (Carrie) Tobkin, Amy (Chris) Tobkin and Beth (Tony) Merschman. Art is also survived by fourteen grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren.

In lieu of flowers, checks can be made out to the “Clearwater County Veteran’s Memorial” or the “Irvin Blix Post #16 Honor Guard”.

Messages of condolence may be sent to ceasefuneralhome.com.

John H. Johnson “Johnny” (B. 03/27/1934; D. 06/15/2024) died at the age of 90. He was the son of Nels and Dena (Sunderland) Johnson. Born and raised on a small farm north of Bagley, he obtained his GED at age 30. He was drafted into the Army in January 1957 and honorably discharged 2 years later. Like many at the time, it was his first adventure outside of the county and it started with train and bus rides to Seattle, WA for training before his post in Germany. He did a lot of driving there and when he returned home, he stopped in Minneapolis for his first used car. He met Nancy Harmon in Bagley and they married on March 12, 1965. The west was calling to both of them, so they hooked up their small trailer and followed Hwy 2 the 1,000 miles to Kalispell, MT where they made their home until she passed in October 2016. They had been married over 51 years. They were devoted to each other and poured countless hours of love and attention onto whichever small white dog they were raising at the time. They both learned to play acoustic and bass guitar and provided worship services for nursing home residents. Johnny believed in the healing power of prayer and maintained that deep faith and ability to pray even when all other memories had faded.

Johnny made a career out of his ability to repair small engines. He continued fixing and repairing small engines into their retirement years by buying used items at garage sales, fixing and painting them to look new with Nancy doing the bookkeeping. By far, their most notable sale was a riding lawnmower to singer/actor Jim Nabors. They even had a chance to play music while he sang on their front porch.

They made several trips back to MN to visit family and friends and welcomed all when we ventured to their neck of the woods. They used their camper to winter in Arizona a few times and made several national park trips with Nancy’s mother, Ida. Johnny could be a bit of a clown – climbing a tree like a monkey into his 50’s or riding a bicycle sitting on the seat backwards. That’s probably when he developed his favorite phrase “I don’t know if I’m a’comin or a’goin.” He and Nancy played a lot of pool and worked on several jigsaw puzzles when there wasn’t a garden or lawn that needed tending. Garage and auction sales provided plenty of opportunities to spend their free time and find great finds for their engine repair business. They also did daily Bible devotions together.

Family moved Johnny to MN when it became apparent that his memory loss was more than he could handle. He had been alone for almost five years and felt so blessed and happy to be surrounded by staff and other residents at the memory care assisted living in Monticello. He provided piano music daily to staff and residents until he lost the ability with a bout of COVID.

Johnny is survived by sisters-in-law, Carol Olsen (Staples, MN) and Carrie Harmon (Clearbrook, MN), and several nephews and nieces.

He was preceded in death by his parents; wife, Nancy; sister, Joyce Dobson; nephew, Allen Dobson; and brothers-in-law, Alvin (Betty) Harmon, David Harmon, and Donald Olsen.

A Celebration of Life is planned for both Johnny and Nancy on Sunday, June 23, 2024, at Saron Lutheran Church, 311 Lake St S, Big Lake, MN 55309, at 1:00 pm followed by a luncheon. A burial service will be held in Kalispell, MT on a later date.

The Peterson-Grimsmo Funeral Chapel in Monticello, MN is assisting with arrangements. www.peterson-grimsmochapel.com.

Adeline May Gohl Beltz passed away peacefully on June 8, 2024, at Sanford Bemidji Medical Center with her daughter Kim at her side.

Adeline was born May 31, 1933, at home in southeast Bagley to Joseph and Beata Gohl (delivered by midwife Feranda Foldo a neighbor). She was baptized on February 19, 1937, and confirmed in 1945 at St. Joseph’s Catholic Church in Bagley. She graduated as an honor student from the Bagley Public School in 1951. From 1951 to 1971 she was employed at the Farmers Publishing Company as bookkeeper and Linotype operator. She was married to Eugene M. Beltz, Sr. on July 22, 1954. They had one daughter, Kim Louise. In 1970 Adeline graduated from Bemidji State College with honors in Elementary Education. From 1972 to 1992 she was employed by Ind. School District 162 in Bagley as a Special Ed. Teacher working with handicapped and special education students. In 1982 she was chosen Clearwater County First Lady of the Year for her work with special education students and her church involvement. She was chosen as Teacher of the Year in 1976 at Ind. School Dist. 162. Husband Eugene passed away in 1985. Adeline retired from teaching in 1992. She was an active member of St. Anne’s Guild and various parish committees. She was able to enjoy traveling with friends to several countries. She began weaving on a floor loom and displayed and sold her wares at craft shows in the area. She used her computer skills to write numerous booklets with a history emphasis. She continued her church service and was awarded the Bishop’s Medal from the Diocese of Crookston. She also became interested in gardening and could be seen daily working in her flower beds. She loved learning new things and was an avid reader. She watched the Mass daily online, attended church as often as she could and was devoted to Bible study and her church. She enjoyed working on her computer, kept up on emails and was always “googling” for new information. She kept up the genealogy on both sides of her family and loved to stay in contact with everyone. She was an avid Twins fan and recently learned to watch Wild hockey games with a nephew while they texted back and forth. She was ever the teacher and always wanted others to be inspired to be better. She took to heart Jesus’ words “Love one another as I have loved you” (John 13:34).

She is survived by her daughter Kim Louise Beltz LaVine (Dan), grandchildren Joe LaVine (Karen: great grandchildren Gabriel, Avery and Allison), Briana Leigh (Chris: great grandchildren William, Dani, Adeline, Cora) and Kyler LaVine(Caitlyn: Great-Grandson Gibson), grandchildren Steve Beltz (Shirley: great-grandchildren Mark and Stephanie), Tom Beltz (Shirley: great-grandchildren Colin and Ross), Mary Pat Rapp (Kieth) and Jane Stash (Tom: great-grandchildren Jenny and Kevin), Mike Beltz (Cindy: great-grandchildren Brittany and Nicole) and Mark Beltz (Julie: great-grandchildren Christine and Eric) her sister Avis Calkins and several great-great grandchildren.

She was preceded in death by her spouse Eugene, his sons and wives Herbert Beltz and spouse Opal, Eugene Beltz Jr. and spouse Lorraine, Shirley Traaseth Beltz, sisters and brothers Alois, Albin, Arthur, Arthur, Andrew, Azela and Adrian.

Funeral Mass will be on Thursday, July 18 at St. Joseph’s Catholic Church at 11:00, with burial to follow at the Bagley Cemetery.

Funeral arrangements will be assisted by Cease Family Funeral Home. Messages of condolence may be sent to ceasefuneralhome.com.

Jeff Riewer, 57, of Walker, MN, formerly of Bagley, died on Sunday, June 9, 2024, at his residence outside of Walker, Minnesota.

Funeral services will be held on Saturday, June 15, 2024, at the St. Joseph’s Catholic Church in Bagley, Minnesota at 2:00 p.m. with Father JohnMelkies Suvakeen officiating. Visitation will be on Friday, June 14, 2024, at the St. Joseph’s Catholic Church in Bagley from 5:00pm – 7:00 pm. A rosary will be held at 6:30 pm and a prayer service will be held at 7:00 pm. A time of sharing will be held after the prayer service. Visitation will also be one hour prior to the service at the church. Interment will be held at the St. Joseph’s Catholic Cemetery immediately after the funeral. The Cease Family Funeral Home of Bagley assisted the family with arrangements.

Jeff was born July 4, 1966, at Bemidji, MN, the son of Leroy and Connie (Strandlien) Riewer. Jeff grew up in Bagley, where he was very active in the 4-H. Jeff won several trips to the Minnesota State Fair showing his sheep. Harold Joseph Shellum, a husband, father, and friend, died peacefully on March 30, 2024, at 105 years old.

Harold was born in 1919 and grew up with five siblings in Minnesota, where he studied in Bagley and graduated with math and social studies degrees from Bemidji State Teacher’s College in 1941. During this time, Harold also developed a lifelong interest: football, which he played, coached, and later devoutly watched for the rest of his life.

After a brief stint teaching, Harold entered the Army Air Force at the onset of WWII, bypassing basic training. After a minor detour in the service, he was admitted to the Cadet program and the University of Chicago for Meteorology training. Upon completion of his cadet program, Harold was initially sent to New Guinea, and after that he followed the war throughout the South Pacific Theater, forecasting the weather for the pilots in such locations as Australia, the Admiralty Islands, the Philippines, Okinawa, and Korea. Harold remained in the reserves after WWII ended, during which time he was promoted from First Lieutenant to Captain. He was hired into the US Weather Bureau in 1947 until he was called to Active-Duty status in 1952 for the Air Force, then resumed his work after being honorably discharged in 1953. Harold worked for the National Weather Service until his retirement in 1979, living in Colorado, Maryland, and finally, California, where he, his wife Ruth, and two daughters Roberta and Cynthia settled. Harold ended his weather bureau career as a Lead Forecaster at the San Francisco station.

Harold’s life was so much more colorful than just his military and career accomplishments. Wherever he went, he was funny, kind, and sociable, befriending others and becoming involved in his community. He met his lifelong partner Ruth on a road trip to California. Married in 1947, they moved several times with Harold’s career advances. Since they lived far away from their families in Minnesota, many vacations were spent visiting their families in the Bagley area and the Appleton area- and on the way Harold insisted the family visit many of the National Parks. In retirement, Harold and Ruth continued to love traveling, once again visiting family and treasured old friends in many different locations.

After 63 years of marriage, at the age of 92, Harold lost his beloved wife Ruth to cancer. Adjusting to a new life as a widower, he continued to play pinochle with the guys. He kept up his hobby of woodworking- making an altar and plant stand, and other cabinetry for his church. He also took up swimming at the YMCA in Monrovia until the age of 101, when the pool closed in the pandemic. He loved seeing family and was thrilled to be asked to represent 2 decades of football alumni at Bemidji State U and to be the Grand Marshall of the Homecoming parade when he was 96. He was so happy that many family members and old friends made it to California to celebrate his 100th birthday. He made several trips back to MN to see family- his last one being at the age of 103!! Always, exercising, he kept moving until 3 ½ weeks before he passed away. Harold had been a singer his whole life but in his old age he was frequently caught humming and singing old hymns and melodies.

To his friends and family, Harold’s impressive ability to recall facts and numbers was unmatched. He could recite facts and information from decades past, and recount stories as if they were recent accounts. This benefited historians as he was able to share his military experience with the Library of Congress as a WWII veteran.

Suffice it to say, Harold never stopped being a light to those around him. In his 105 years, he cultivated a life of friends and family who remember him fondly and admirably, from his singing to his service in the Air Force to his commitment to God and the love for his entire family. Though Harold’s wife Ruth and seven siblings preceded him in death, his legacy lives on in his daughters Roberta and Cindy (Jim), grandchildren Gretchen (Louis), Kari (Michael), Christian (Gabby), Jenny (Travis), Elizabeth (Ryan), Keira, and eight great-grandchildren.

Gerald Hardy Wraa was born March 11,1922 and died May 15, 2024, at the age of 102.

Gerald lived the early years of his childhood in Stevens, MN. At the age of 8, the family moved to Windsor Township with their belongings in a wagon pulled by horses, and their cows following behind. They camped out at night as they made their way, and at times Gerald (although only 8 years old) was required to handle the reigns of the wagon.

Gerald graduated from the 8th grade in Gonvick, MN and chose the CCC camp near Cass Lake for his higher education. There they lived through the severe Armistice Day winter storm which was not forecast and caught hundreds of people away from safety in Northern MN. The young men were sent out to rescue lost hunters & found frozen bodies caught in the unexpected storm. He learned a variety of skills while there (including dog robber? haha), logging and other conservation skills and living in a military type setting.

Gerald was in Oslo, MN working on his car when he said, “Ma came out and told me the Japanese bombed Pearl Harbor, and I knew my fate was sealed”. He joined the US Navy in 1942 and served aboard the Destroyer, US Arleigh Burke, as a 40MM gunner and was a planker (the first crew to serve aboard a new naval vessel). Gerald received numerous medals and war time ribbons, including a purple heart. History also shows that the squadron of destroyers he served with, received a Presidential Citation for the most perfect battle in Naval History at the Battle of Cape St. George, which is still used today to train Naval tactics. When a plane was shot down, and the crew of his destroyer rescued the pilot, the pilot’s name was Pappy Boyington.

When the war ended, Gerald left his shipmates in 1946 and came back to MN, where in 1947 he married his soul mate Edna Davis. When the young couple homesteaded in Clover Township, Gerald cut the trees, cleared the land, and built a small cabin himself. Gerald and Edna raised three sons: Jerry L, Joel, and Steve. Through the years Gerald farmed and was a logger and later a cement mason. When formal training was not an option to learn masonry, Gerald prayed that God would teach him and he became a natural at his trade, and even worked in supervisory positions.

Gerald served in the capacity of the township clerk in Clover for 60 years. He and Edna were charter members of Clover Chapel. In later years, they became members of the First Baptist Church of Clearbrook. He was a longtime member of the Clearbrook Legion Post 256, a life member of the Bemidji VFW Post 1260, and a life Member of Bemidji DAV. Other items of his life legacy include that he was a charter member of the Leonard American Legion Post and served as Grand Marshall of the Leonard 100-year celebration parade at age 100.

He and Edna celebrated their 50th anniversary at the Clover Chapel, their 70th anniversary at the Clearbrook Baptist church, and their 75th anniversary at the Memorial Day celebration in Clearbrook. May 31, 2024, would have been their 77th anniversary.

He was preceded in death by his parents, Gilbert and Maudy (Blake) Wraa, his sister Lorraine (Wraa) Kasmatka and brother Glenn. He is survived by his wife Edna, one brother Don (Deb), sons Jerry L. (Lana), Joel, Steve (Julie), 7 grandchildren, 13 great grandchildren and numerous nieces and nephews.

Oran Gerald Underdahl was born at home on March 28, 1941, near Fertile, Minnesota, to parents Art and Alvina Olson Underdahl. He had an older sister, Anna. He was baptized at Little Norway Lutheran Church of rural Fertile before moving with his family to the farm south of Fosston in 1943. He attended Willow Grove Country School through 8th grade before earning his diploma from Fosston High School in 1958. He was confirmed in his faith at Hope Lutheran Church in Fosston. As a boy, he enjoyed drawing pictures of bucking broncos and rodeos he imagined, participating in all kinds of 4-H activities, riding horse, trapping around the lake, and singing baritone in the school choir.

After high school, he dairy and grain farmed with his father and grandfather briefly before enlisting in the Army and serving at White Sands Missile Range, New Mexico until 1965. After discharge, Oran returned home to Fosston where he resumed farming alongside his father, purchasing the operation from his parents in 1977 and continuing until 1997. Oran was united in marriage to Geri Mahto on November 22, 1980, at First Baptist Church in Clearbrook, Minnesota. After their marriage, he lived with Geri and her two children, Kris and Robin, on the farm and they welcomed their daughter, Sarah, in 1981. Together, Oran and Geri enjoyed participating in church functions, growing a garden, serving on the Rosebud Township Board, visiting and playing games with friends, and watching the kids in all their school activities. Geri passed away in 2003.

Brett Newland tragically passed away in a car accident on January 19, 2024, in Iowa. Brett Ryan Newland was born February 15, 1971, in Texas. He and his brother Jared Jon were adopted by Larry and Caryll Newland and we were overjoyed to have those cute little boys, with their curly hair, join our family. Brett had fond memories growing up and especially loved spending time with his brothers Kelly and Jared at their grandparents’ farm fishing, hunting, and playing with cousins. Brett attended elementary school in Grand Forks, ND before moving to Eagan and then to Rosemount. Brett graduated high school from Peniel Christian School in Wisconsin. Following high school, Brett served in the Navy. He was very proud of his service to our country.

Brett met the love of his life, Laura, and they were married on October 31, 2014. They were best friends, had much in common and loved riding their motorcycles together whenever they could. Brett was so excited to purchase his first Harley Davidson and loved sharing pictures of his prized bike and all their adventures. Brett and Laura started a new career driving semi-truck across the country and they drove as a team the last few years. He enjoyed life on the road with Laura and their two little dogs. Brett was a hard worker, and he was so happy about his accomplishments despite having some difficult challenges in life. His family was proud of him.

Brett had a big personality, a big heart and touched many people throughout his life. His family and friends were very important to Brett and he was always there to lend a hand where he could. Brett held a special place in his heart for his sweet daughter Cora who he lovingly referred to as Corabelle. She was his pride and joy. Brett loved his parents very much. He bonded with his dad over talks about tractors, engines and cars and he adored his sweet mom who faithfully prayed for him throughout his life.

Brett is survived by his loving wife Laura (Iowa), parents Larry & Caryll Newland (Northfield), brother Kelly (Diana) (Indiana), daughter Cora Isabelle Fluharty (Iowa), Grandma Evelyn Newland (Mora), stepdaughters Xanadu (Brandon) Weaver, Brittany (Austin) Ebner, grandsons Tiernan & Dechlan Ebner and granddaughter Mayhem Weaver (Iowa). Brett is also survived by numerous special Aunties, Uncles, nephews, nieces, sister and brother in laws, cousins, special friend Kelly Frock and numerous other friends he met throughout his life. Brett will be dearly missed by all.

Brett was preceded in death by brothers, Jared and Samuel, Grandparents-Monroe Newland, Thomas & Irene Thompson, Uncles-Wayne & Ross Thompson, & Jim Newland, Aunt Marlys Hanson, mother and father-in-law Daniel & Vicky Klinger, brother-in-law Daniel Klinger and sister-in-law Diann Klinger.

A Celebration of Life will be held at Minnesota Valley Church, 16075 Hawthorn Path, Lakeville, MN on March 16 at 1:00 pm with visitation one hour prior. A luncheon will be served following the service.
